posts.name: jimfl014
posts.cooked:
Hi!  We were thinking of using a FIRST approved air cylinder as a brake for our lower arm section.  The cylinder would not be attached to a compressor, it would just have relief valves to slow the air flow and create drag.

Is this legal?

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
While I cannot comment absolutely on a hypothetical robot design, there is no rule prohibiting what you have described.

Also, you’re describing a damper. You could use a damper that is lighter and cheaper than an air cylinder.

posts.name: Jeffrey Morris
posts.cooked:
I think what you’re looking for is a needle valve?

Alternatively maybe a gas shock.

posts.name: jimfl014
posts.cooked:
We might go the gas strut route, now that I found a place in NC that has some in stock.  I will also look at the damper as well

Thanks for the suggestions and clarification on the terminology!

On another option that we are planning on using is some pretty strong constant force springs on the back side of our arm to help control it. It will take some load off of the motor trying to hold it in position too.

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked:

IMG_20230213_075131620 1920×1440 282 KB

There are a million reasons why you want to achieve as close to neutral buoyancy as possible on your arm. Maybe not a million, but definitely several.

Less stress on the joint. Less work for your motor (and thus less drain on your battery). Less gearing needed (so lighter weight). Higher degree of control.

Gas shocks are pretty cheap, and when you don’t need a huge range of motion, do the job just fine.

To play devil’s advocate for a moment, is there any risk this setup could be considered to be a compressor? The setup described by the OP sounds safe, but if the same concept were carried to the extreme, wouldn’t it be possible to blow a tank?

I love the creative idea. As others have mentioned, you’re essentially creating a gas shock. Any auto supply store should carry them.

EDIT: to clarify that you would want a liftgate shock, not one for your suspension.

If you don’t mind where did you get the coiled pneumatic lines?

Edit: nevermind I found some on automation direct

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.custom_user_title: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
I think there was a Q&A last year about using the exhaust side of your pneumatics to cool your motors and asking if the motors had to be considered pneumatic devices because they were technically at a higher pressure than atmosphere.

The answer basically said as long as it’s eventually connected to atmosphere at the end then it’s all part of the exhaust and nothing on there is a pneumatic device.

This is kind of the same situation.  The cylinder is connected to atmosphere.

But the flow control added will cause pressure to build up, and you are probably using a powered arm motion to compress the air in there, so in some ways this is a different situation.

Closed cycle gas shocks are explicitly allowed for this kind of thing.

If using a cylinder it would be worth carefully reading the rules again and possibly asking a Q&A about it.

Specifically you’re looking to be in the exception listed in the blue box under R804 (M):

… so you’d have to convince the LRI that it can’t “contain pressurized air.”

posts.name: jimfl014
posts.cooked:
I used a fishing scale attached to the arm, perpendicular to the force to get a reading.

One of the students cleverly attached a piston to the arm at the mounting point we desire, put 60 lbs into the system and started testing.  At 40lbs the pressure is just enough to resist it and provide no back drive.

Appropriate gas strut is on order.

Thought that was clever
